pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 206, 366, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 185, 907, 200]]<|/det|>
0625/23  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 207, 907, 222]]<|/det|>
May/June 2019  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 228, 907, 242]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 544, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 388, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 342, 237, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 357, 504, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 372, 892, 401]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 383, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 429, 892, 459]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 459, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 488, 556, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 517, 764, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 533, 467, 548]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 549, 359, 564]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 564, 630, 579]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 737, 89]]<|/det|> Which quantity can be measured directly using a micrometer screw gauge? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 134, 118]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 384, 118]]<|/det|> the area of a sheet of paper <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 127, 134, 144]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 127, 390, 144]]<|/det|> the mass of a sheet of paper <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 153, 134, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 153, 425, 170]]<|/det|> the thickness of a sheet of paper <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 179, 134, 196]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 179, 406, 196]]<|/det|> the volume of a sheet of paper <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 97, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 222, 586, 240]]<|/det|> A brass ball and a feather are released at the same time. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 253, 470, 270]]<|/det|> On Earth, the ball reaches the ground first. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 284, 564, 301]]<|/det|> On the Moon, they reach the ground at the same time. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 314, 384, 331]]<|/det|> What is the explanation for this? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 342, 134, 359]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 342, 440, 359]]<|/det|> Both weigh the same on the Moon. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 368, 134, 386]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 368, 398, 384]]<|/det|> Both weigh less on the Moon. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 394, 131, 413]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 394, 529, 411]]<|/det|> There is a greater air resistance on the Moon. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 420, 133, 439]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 420, 477, 437]]<|/det|> There is no air resistance on the Moon. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 464, 96, 483]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 464, 920, 496]]<|/det|> A heavy metal ball falls vertically downwards through air past four equally spaced levels J, K, L and M. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 505, 635, 675]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 691, 638, 708]]<|/det|> The times taken to fall from one level to the next are measured. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 721, 667, 739]]<|/det|> Where is the speed of the ball greatest and which time is shortest? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 750, 529, 897]]<|/det|>
speed is
greatest between		time is
shortest between
AJ and KJ and K
BJ and KL and M
CL and MJ and K
DL and ML and M

The change in gravitational potential energy of the body depends upon its mass \(m\), the change in height \(\Delta h\) and the gravitational field strength \(g\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 737, 767, 755]]<|/det|> What is the correct expression for the change in gravitational potential energy? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 768, 134, 787]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 768, 201, 787]]<|/det|> $gm\Delta h$ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 765, 306, 784]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[321, 763, 356, 784]]<|/det|> \(\frac{gm}{\Delta h}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 763, 475, 782]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 761, 529, 782]]<|/det|> \(\frac{g\Delta h}{m}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[613, 765, 640, 784]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[656, 764, 702, 784]]<|/det|> $m\Delta h$ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[663, 781, 688, 798]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 797, 133, 816]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 797, 203, 816]]<|/det|> $gm\Delta h$ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 797, 131, 816]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 797, 153, 816]]<|/det|> $gm\Delta h$ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 797, 131, 816]]<|/det|>

The water is stirred until the temperature of the water has fallen to \(0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 800, 361, 817]]<|/det|> 18 g of ice remains unmelted. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 831, 514, 848]]<|/det|> The specific heat capacity of water is \(4.2 \text{J} /\text{g} ^{\circ}\text{C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 860, 789, 878]]<|/det|> Which value does this experiment give for the specific latent heat of fusion of ice? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 889, 133, 907]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 889, 220, 907]]<|/det|> 210 J/g <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 889, 291, 907]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 889, 388, 907]]<|/det|> 330 J/g <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 889, 462, 907]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 889, 552, 907]]<|/det|> 580 J/g <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 889, 631, 907]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 889, 720, 907]]<|/det|> 770 J/g

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 868, 89]]<|/det|>
Why does a metal rod conduct thermal energy much better than a similar-sized plastic rod?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 133, 117]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 828, 117]]<|/det|>
The molecules in the plastic are much closer together than the atoms in the metal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 127, 133, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 125, 752, 144]]<|/det|>
The molecules in the plastic are much larger than the atoms in the metal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 257, 106, 275]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 256, 922, 291]]<|/det|> A beam of light passes through a vacuum and then enters a liquid. The diagram shows the path it takes. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 303, 628, 448]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 459, 653, 478]]<|/det|> The light travels through the vacuum at a speed of \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 490, 437, 508]]<|/det|> What is the speed of light in the liquid? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 520, 128, 537]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 520, 267, 537]]<|/det|> \(1.9 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 547, 128, 565]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 547, 267, 565]]<|/det|> \(2.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 574, 128, 592]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 574, 267, 592]]<|/det|> \(4.6 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 602, 128, 619]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 602, 267, 619]]<|/det|> \(4.8 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 645, 106, 664]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 645, 828, 663]]<|/det|> An eclipse of the Sun happens when the Moon comes between the Earth and the Sun. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 675, 348, 693]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 703, 131, 722]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 703, 870, 721]]<|/det|> Infra-red radiation from the Sun disappears before visible light and ultra-violet radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 730, 131, 748]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 730, 871, 747]]<|/det|> Ultra-violet radiation from the Sun disappears before visible light and infra-red radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 757, 131, 775]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 757, 871, 774]]<|/det|> Visible light from the Sun disappears before ultra-violet radiation and infra-red radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 784, 131, 802]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 784, 920, 816]]<|/det|> Infra-red radiation, ultra-violet radiation and visible light from the Sun all disappear at the same moment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|> A pulse of sound is produced at the bottom of a boat. The sound travels through the water and is reflected from a shoal of fish. The sound reaches the boat again after 1.2 s. The speed of sound in the water is \(1500 \text{m / s}\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 128, 635, 240]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 252, 588, 271]]<|/det|> How far below the bottom of the boat is the shoal of fish? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 280, 134, 299]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 280, 170, 299]]<|/det|> 450 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 280, 303, 299]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[310, 280, 373, 299]]<|/det|> 900 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 280, 470, 299]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 280, 545, 299]]<|/det|> 1800 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 280, 638, 299]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[643, 280, 717, 299]]<|/det|> 3600 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 325, 106, 344]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 325, 494, 344]]<|/det|> Which statement about ultrasound is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 354, 134, 373]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 354, 762, 373]]<|/det|> It has a higher frequency than audible sound, and it is a longitudinal wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 380, 131, 399]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 380, 755, 399]]<|/det|> It has a higher frequency than audible sound, and it is a transverse wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 406, 131, 425]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 406, 755, 425]]<|/det|> It has a lower frequency than audible sound, and it is a longitudinal wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 432, 133, 451]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 432, 747, 451]]<|/det|> It has a lower frequency than audible sound, and it is a transverse wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 476, 106, 495]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 476, 730, 495]]<|/det|> A metal bar is placed inside a current-carrying coil, as shown in diagram 1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 507, 813, 526]]<|/det|> There is a small current in the coil. The bar holds a few nails, as shown in diagram 2. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 533, 776, 630]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 643, 559, 662]]<|/det|> When there is no current in the coil, the nails drop off. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 675, 297, 692]]<|/det|> Which row is correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 702, 625, 852]]<|/det|>
metal from which the bar is madeeffect of a larger current in the coil
Asoft ironit makes no difference
Bsoft ironthe bar holds more nails
Csteelit makes no difference
Dsteelthe bar holds more nails

charge on stripsforce between strips

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 549, 104, 567]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 549, 524, 567]]<|/det|> A cell has an electromotive force (e.m.f.) of 1.5 V. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 580, 391, 597]]<|/det|> What does this statement mean? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 607, 136, 625]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 607, 866, 625]]<|/det|> The cell converts 1.0 J of energy when driving 1.5 C of charge round a complete circuit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 634, 136, 652]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 634, 866, 651]]<|/det|> The cell converts 1.5 J of energy when driving 1.0 C of charge round a complete circuit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 660, 136, 678]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 660, 920, 693]]<|/det|> The cell converts 1.5 J of energy per second when driving 1.0 C of charge round a complete circuit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 701, 134, 719]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 701, 868, 719]]<|/det|> The cell converts 1.5 W of power when driving 1.0 C of charge round a complete circuit.

<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 853, 89]]<|/det|>
A student is designing a lighting circuit for a dolls' house. He sets up two different circuits.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 677, 119]]<|/det|>
Each circuit contains a \(12\mathrm{V}\) power supply and three identical lamps.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 922, 166]]<|/det|>
Each lamp is designed to operate at normal brightness when connected individually to a \(12\mathrm{V}\) supply.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 173, 828, 352]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 364, 348, 382]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 394, 134, 411]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 394, 594, 411]]<|/det|>
In circuit 1, each of the lamps is at normal brightness.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 420, 131, 438]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 420, 601, 438]]<|/det|>
In circuit 1, if one lamp fails, the other lamps remain lit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 446, 131, 465]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 446, 601, 464]]<|/det|>
In circuit 2, if one lamp fails, the other lamps remain lit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 472, 131, 490]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 472, 717, 490]]<|/det|>
In circuit 2, the current from the power supply is less than in circuit 1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 515, 106, 533]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 515, 687, 533]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 540, 648, 594]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 609, 589, 626]]<|/det|>
Which single logic gate is equivalent to this combination?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 636, 138, 655]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 636, 195, 655]]<|/det|>
AND

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 636, 316, 655]]<|/det|>
B

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 636, 364, 655]]<|/det|>
NOR

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 636, 475, 655]]<|/det|>
C

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 636, 527, 655]]<|/det|>
NOT

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 576, 90]]<|/det|>
A simple wiring diagram for an electric cooker is shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 97, 707, 323]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 333, 688, 352]]<|/det|>
Why is there a wire connecting the metal case of the cooker to earth?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 361, 134, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 361, 475, 380]]<|/det|>
It improves the efficiency of the cooker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 388, 133, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 388, 777, 406]]<|/det|>
It prevents the metal case from becoming too hot when the cooker is left on.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 414, 131, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 414, 784, 432]]<|/det|>
It reduces the risk of an electric shock if the live wire touches the metal case.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 441, 133, 459]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 441, 539, 459]]<|/det|>
The electric cooker will not switch on without it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 486, 104, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>36</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 486, 430, 504]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles are directed at a metal foil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 516, 700, 535]]<|/det|>
Most of the particles pass through the foil with little change in direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 546, 730, 565]]<|/det|>
A small proportion of the particles are scattered back through large angles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 575, 653, 594]]<|/det|>
What does this evidence suggest about the structure of an atom?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 605, 134, 623]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 605, 920, 638]]<|/det|>
It consists of a charged centre much smaller than the size of the atom and with little of the mass of the atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 647, 134, 665]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 647, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
It consists of a negative charge the size of the atom containing small positive charges scattered through it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 688, 131, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 688, 920, 720]]<|/det|>
It consists of a charged centre much smaller than the size of the atom but with most of the mass of the atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 728, 134, 746]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 728, 920, 761]]<|/det|>
It consists of a positive charge the size of the atom containing small negative charges scattered through it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 606, 89]]<|/det|> A conductor carrying a current is placed in a magnetic field. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 569, 119]]<|/det|> In which direction does the force on the conductor act? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 129, 690, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 285, 107, 303]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 285, 316, 303]]<|/det|> What is nuclear fission? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 313, 134, 331]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 313, 589, 331]]<|/det|> the merging of two nuclei to create a heavier nucleus <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 339, 134, 357]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 339, 631, 357]]<|/det|> the process by which electrons are removed from an atom <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 365, 134, 384]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 365, 514, 383]]<|/det|> the process by which stars generate energy <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 392, 133, 410]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 392, 584, 409]]<|/det|> the splitting of a nucleus to create two smaller nuclei <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 435, 106, 454]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 435, 490, 454]]<|/det|> Which statement about \(\gamma\) -radiation is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 464, 133, 483]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 464, 497, 482]]<|/det|> It consists of very small charged particles. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 490, 133, 508]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 490, 480, 508]]<|/det|> It is a form of electromagnetic radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 517, 131, 536]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 517, 465, 536]]<|/det|> It is less penetrating than \(\beta\) -radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 545, 133, 562]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 545, 494, 562]]<|/det|> It is more highly ionising than \(\alpha\) -radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 590, 104, 607]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 590, 747, 607]]<|/det|> A radium nucleus with nucleon number 226 decays by emitting an \(\alpha\) -particle. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 621, 408, 638]]<|/det|> The proton number of radium is 88. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 650, 860, 668]]<|/det|> What are the nucleon number and proton number for the nucleus produced by this decay?
